review.title: A Formal Characterization of the Local Search Topology of the Gap Heuristic
review.abstract: The pancake puzzle is a classic optimization problem that has become a standard benchmark for heuristic search algorithms. In this paper, we provide full proofs regarding the local search topology of the gap heuristic for the pancake puzzle. First, we show that in any non-goal state in which there is no move that will decrease the number of gaps, there is a move that will keep the number of gaps constant. We then classify any state in which the number of gaps cannot be decreased in a single action into two groups: those requiring 2 actions to decrease the number of gaps, and those which require 3 actions to decrease the number of gaps.
histories: Technical report providing proofs of statements appearing in a "An Analysis and Enhancement of the Gap Heuristic for the Pancake Puzzle" by Richard Anthony Valenzano and Danniel Yang. This paper appeared at the 2017 Symposium on Combinatorial Search

sections.heading: 3 Topology of the Gap Heuristic
sections.text: In this section, we expand on the work of Fischer and Ginzinger (2005) and provide a classification of the states according to the size of the plateaus around them. To simplify this analysis, we assume that in all states there is a gap between the sites N and N + 1. Thus, the postfix of a state is cancelled if it is already sorted, since this part of the state will have no effect on the number of gaps or the optimal solution costs. So we start with an additional notation. Following Hoffmann (2005), a plateau for h is a contiguous set of one or more states, all of which have the same heuristic value. An exit from a plateau with heuristic value is a state.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have provided the complete evidence underlying a characterization of the topology of gap heuristics. Firstly, we have shown that there is a gap-neutral movement in each non-targeted state. Secondly, we have provided a classification that organizes the states according to whether the number of gaps can be reduced in 1, 2 or 3 actions.
